medical: EXAM: Ultrasound-guided paracentesis HISTORY: Ascites. TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent was obtained from the patient after the risks and benefits of the procedure were thoroughly explained. Ultrasound demonstrates free fluid in the abdomen. The area of interest was localized with ultrasonography. The region was sterilely prepped and draped in the usual manner. Local anesthetic was administered. A 5-French Yueh catheter needle combination was taken. Upon crossing into the peritoneal space and aspiration of fluid, the catheter was advanced out over the needle. A total of approximately 5500 mL of serous fluid was obtained. The catheter was then removed. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate postprocedure complications. IMPRESSION: Ultrasound-guided paracentesis as above.
layman:
EXAM: Ultrasound‑guided paracentesis

HISTORY: The patient has ascites (fluid buildup in the belly).

TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: The patient was fully informed about the risks and benefits and gave consent. Ultrasound showed fluid in the abdomen. The exact spot for the needle was found using the ultrasound. The area was cleaned and covered in a sterile way. A local numbing medicine was given. A small needle and catheter (5‑French Yueh) were used. The needle was inserted into the belly cavity and fluid was drawn out. The catheter was then pulled out over the needle. About 5,500 mL of clear fluid was removed. The catheter was taken out. The patient did well and had no problems right after the procedure.

IMPRESSION: The ultrasound‑guided paracentesis was performed as described.
